(43)110th Conclusions.Copy No.WAR CABINET 110 (43).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10 Downing Street,.S.W.l,on Wednesday, Ath August, 1943, at 1 p.m.Present:The Right Hon. Winston S. Churchill, M.P., Prime Minister (in the Chair).The Right Hon. C. R. Attlee, M.P.,Secretary of State for DominionAffairs. :sThe Right Hon. Oliver Lyttelton,M.P., Minister of Production.The Right Hon. Anthony Eden, M.P.secretary of State for ForeignAffairs.The Right Hon. Herbert Morrison,M.P., Secretary of State for theHome Department and Minister ofHome Security.The following were also presentThe Right Hon. Viscount Cranborne,Lord Privy Seal.The Right Hon. Sir archibald sinclair, Bt., M.P., Secretary ofState for Air.Admiral of the Fleet Sir dudley pound, First Sea Lord and Chief ofNaval Staff.General Sir Alan Brooke, Chief of theImperial. General Staff.The Right Hon. Sir James Grigg,M.P., Secretary of State for War.The Right Hon. Sir Stafford Cripps,K.C., M.P., Minister of aircraft production.Air Chief Marshal Sir Charles F. A.Portal, Chief of the Air Staff.*Vice-Admiral Lord Louis Mount-batten, Chief of Combined Opera-tions.Secretariat:Sir Edward Bridges.Lieutenant-General Sir Hastings Ismay.- Contents.minute no. Subject.1 Air Policy .... ....Bombing of Borne.2 France ............. ....Committee of National -Liberation.Page.204 /Ms Policy.Bombing ofBorne.(Previous 'Befereuce:W.M.(43) 101stConclusions,Minute 4.)France.Committee, ofNationalLiberation.(previous reference:W.M. (43) 99thConclusions,Minute 1.)9n, \- ,The War Cabinet had a further discussion on this mattercontatneHn nL*H dis(?ssion "4 ? the Conclusions reached isConcluTions Secretary's Standard File of War cabinet. The Prime Minister read to the War Cabinet telegramNo. 343 from, the President, saying that he hoped nothing wouldbe done in the matter of the recognition of the Committee ofNational Liberation until the President and the Prime minister had had an opportunity to talk it over together.The Prime Minister said that he was proposing to send a.reply, agreeing to this suggestion, but adding that pressure from all quarters was growing in favour of recognising the french committee.He also proposed to send a personal message to Mr. Macmillan,for communication to the leading members of the Committee, to theeffect that he hoped that a decision on this matter would be reachedvery shortly.[This message was conveyed in telegram No. 1553 of the8th August, 1943, to Mr. Macmillan.]The War Cabinet- 'Took note of these statements.Offices of the War Cabinet, S:W. 1,4tth August, 1943.
